keyTakeAways: The Supreme Court will consider whether regular marijuana users can legally possess firearms, marking a direct application of the 2022 Second Amendment ruling that expanded gun rights.
The case involves Ali Danial Hemani, a Texas man who was charged with a felony gun possession charge after being found with a firearm in his home, despite being a regular marijuana user.

The Justice Department appealed the lower court’s decision that struck down a blanket ban on gun ownership for individuals who use illegal drugs, arguing such a ban is a justifiable public safety measure.

The appellate court found the law unconstitutional under the Supreme Court’s 2022 expanded interpretation of gun rights, which emphasizes that firearm restrictions must be grounded in historical precedent.
Hemani’s attorneys argue that the law risks criminalizing millions of Americans, as at least 20% of U.S. adults have tried marijuana, and half of U.S. states have legalized recreational use.

The federal government maintains that regular drug users—especially those with guns—pose a serious public safety risk, citing FBI evidence of gun and cocaine found in Hemani’s home during a probe into Iran-related activities.
The case highlights a broader political and legal conflict between conservative advocacy for Second Amendment rights and government efforts to implement public safety-based firearm restrictions.
This case is a flashpoint in the application of the Supreme Court’s 2022 test for firearm restrictions, which requires that any restriction must have a strong historical basis.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The U.S. Supreme Court has agreed to hear a case questioning whether people who regularly use marijuana can legally possess guns. The case centers on Ali Danial Hemani, a Texas man charged with a felony gun possession charge after being found with a firearm in his home, despite being a regular marijuana user. The Justice Department, under the Trump administration, is appealing a lower court ruling that declared a blanket ban on gun ownership for drug users unconstitutional under the Supreme Court’s 2022 expanded Second Amendment interpretation. Hemani’s attorneys argue the law risks criminalizing millions of Americans, given that at least 20% of U.S. adults have used marijuana. The government counters that regular drug use, especially when paired with guns, poses a public safety risk, citing FBI evidence from Hemani’s home. The case marks a significant flashpoint in the ongoing legal and political debate over firearm rights and drug policy, with arguments expected in early 2026 and a decision likely by early summer. This case also brings attention to the broader political tensions, including the personal connection to Hunter Biden, who was previously convicted under the same law and later pardoned by his father, President Joe Biden.
title: Supreme Court to Consider Gun Rights of Regular Marijuana Users
